Award.AwardTitle: GSE/RES Collaborative Research: Recruitment and Retention of Women in Geosciences: An Investigation of Individual and Environmental Factors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The goal of this proposed collaborative research project is to contribute to the knowledge needed to increase the proportion of women receiving undergraduate geoscience degrees from U.S. universities. The proportion of women earning undergraduate geoscience degrees has stagnated at approximately 40% for the past 6 years, while women constitute only about 20% of working geoscientists. The American Geological Institute reports that the 40% level may represent a ceiling for female geoscience graduates. Most other STEM fields are closer than the geosciences to achieving gender parity. Little empirical research has investigated why women major in geoscience or how women's choices differ from men's choices to select and persist in a geoscience degree. This study would fill this research gap by studying why some geoscience programs are more successful than others at recruiting and retaining a high percentage of female students. Specifically, the researchers will study the characteristics of geoscience programs, students, and faculty at one set of universities with above-average graduation of female geoscience students and another set of universities with below-average graduation of female geoscience students. The study would be guided by Social Cognitive Career Theory and will use mixed methods research methods.

Broader Impacts: This project will contribute to the knowledge needed to increase the proportion of women receiving undergraduate geoscience degrees from U.S. universities. Ultimately, this may increase the proportion of women choosing geosciences careers. Results will be disseminated widely to geosciences departments for recruiting and retaining female geosciences majors including recommendations for concrete steps that may achieve gender parity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proportion of women earning undergraduate geoscience degrees has remained about 40% for over a decade. Little research has investigated why women select and persist in a geoscience major. This study addresses why students major in the geosciences and why some programs are more successful at recruiting and retaining female students.

 

We collected interview and survey data  from faculty and students at six public US universities. Four sites had a low proportion of female degree recipients (< 38%) and two sites had a high proportion of female degree recipients (> 48%). 408 students (64% female) completed surveys. Interviews were conducted with 49 faculty members and 151 students.

 

Survey data analysis showed that interest/identity and transformative experiences were significant predictors of students' decision to major in geoscience. Institutional barriers and supports were significant predictors of confidence in the major while connection to instructor predicted students' intent to major. Analysis of pre- and post-course surveys show that students with a greater connection to instructors and students whose instructors expressed more passion for the content also reported higher levels of transformative experiences. This effect was especially pronounced for women and was a significant predictor of persistence in the major.

 

Qualitative data also showed differences in the gendered equity climate between high and low sites. High sites had more positive gender equity climates and low sites had more negative gender equity climates. Our findings show that recruitment and retention of undergraduate women is associated with department practices, department culture, transformative experience, and connection to instructor. Also, we found that in spite of national success toward reaching numerical parity for the percentage of degrees conferred on women (about 40% nationally), female students encounter hostile and benevolent sexism in classroom and field settings. As the geosciences and other STEM disciplines work toward numerical parity for women graduates, our findings suggest that continued interventions are needed to address sexism.

 

Intellectual Merit: A central concern within the discipline of science education is the recruitment and retention of individuals in STEM fields – with particular concern regarding the recruitment and retention of women. Our research confirms prior research identifying interest and identity as important factors. Moreover, it identifies factors not previously identified: students’ perceptions of their connection to their instructors and students’ degree of transformative experience in relation to course learning. Additionally, previous research has focused on the role of department culture/climate on recruiting and retaining women at the graduate level and faculty level in science. We have identified the role of department practices and culture/climate on undergraduate recruitment and retention. We have also identified differences in the reasons that men and women select a geoscience major.

 

Within the last 50 years, considerable progress has been made in defining and researching issues of motivation and engagement. Our research contributes further progress in this area by expanding our understanding of transformative experience and exploring the relation of this construct to other motivation variables and outcomes such as academic and career choice, particularly in STEM. Transformative experience represents a relatively new area of research, unique from other engagement constructs in that it focuses on engagement extending beyond the classroom. Although research on transformative experience exists, the current study is much larger in scale from prior research and uniquely considers the relation between transformative experience and academic and career choice. Also, research on student engagement and recruitment and retention has largely focused on either 1) institutional efforts to recruit and retain students at the institutional level and 2) the role of department practices to recruit and retain graduate students or faculty. Our study identified department practices and culture that may be critical for the recruitment and retention of undergraduate students, particularly women.

 

Broader Impacts:  Our research is centrally focused on improving access to and retention in geoscience majors for women .  A major economic challenge for the US is the mismatch between professional training and jobs available. Currently, we have many jobs available in STEM fields but too few individuals trained for these jobs, a trend also true in the long term and across sectors for the geosciences. Simply put, too few US students choose to pursue STEM in college. This puts us at great economic risk given projects that STEM jobs will continue to become more central to world economies and other countries are doing a far better job of attracting individuals into STEM careers. Our research provides insight into key factors for attracting individuals (particularly women) into STEM careers.

 

While the project is not an intervention program, it yields insight into why women may be underrepresented in some departments and what factors relate to their recruitment and retention. Dissemination of these results will help geoscience departments improve in this area and increase the number of women pursuing geoscience careers.
